timeline.hover: Political Declaration adopted by the UN General Assembly
timeline.main:
Between 8th June 1998 and 10th June 1998, the United Nations General Assembly in its 20th session on World Drug Problem, adopted a new political declaration and global action plan to combat money laundering. India is a signatory to this declaration.
The declaration called upon member nations to enact national money laundering legislation and programmes in line of the Vienna Convention and the FATF Recommendations by 2003.

timeline.hover:
Enactment of Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (Amendment) Act, 2001 by the Parliament
Insertion of Section 8A and Chapter VA to the Act.
timeline.main:
In the Year 1998 India signed the Political Declaration at the Special Session of the United Nations General Assembly on World Drug Problem.
Pursuant to such declaration, an amendment Bill was introduced before the Parliament which amongst other amendments sought to introduce prohibition of activities related to property derived from drug money and a mechanism to seize, freeze and confiscate such property.
For the first time in India, a comprehensive definition of proceeds of crime (though not under the said name) was introduced. Per this definition, under Section 8A of the Act, the conversion, transfer, act of participation in concealment or disguising the illicit origin of the property or the acquisition, possession or use of such property was considered as a separate offence.
The broad confines of Section 8A of the amended Act was perfectly compliant and in accordance to the Vienna Convention.

timeline.hover: Enactment of the Prevention of Money Laundering Act, 2002 by the Parliament
timeline.main: Act passed by the parliament in compliance of India’s obligation under the Political Declaration signed by India in 1998, at the special session of the United Nations General Assembly.

timeline.hover:
FATF Mutual Evaluation of India (2010)
The definition of Proceeds of Crime under the PMLA was found to be incompatible with the International Standards.
timeline.main:
The Financial Action Task Force conducted the Mutual Evaluation of India and released its Report in 2010. During the evaluation process the FTAF found that the definition of ‘proceeds of crime’ as prescribed under Section 3 of the Prevention of Money Laundering Act, 2002, did not subscribe and adhere to certain key features and requirements under the Vienna and Palermo Conventions.

Two major concerns were highlighted in the Report:
  • The act of physical concealment in the absence of projection was not covered. Further, the PMLA did not extend to the activity of acquisition, possession or use of the proceeds of crime as prescribed under Article 6(1)(b)(i) of the Palermo Convention.
  • The act of money laundering was not construed independent of the predicate offence. Thus, it was recommended that measures be brought into place which would permit the confiscation of proceeds of crime even in the absentia of a conviction under the predicate offence.

timeline.hover:
Prevention of Money Laundering (Amendment) Act, 2012 was enacted by the Parliament
Definition of Money Laundering was overhauled as per FATF Mutual Evaluation (2010).
timeline.main:
Pursuant to the Mutual Evaluation of India conducted under the aegis of the FATF and the change in the FATF recommendations brought about in the year 2012, the Parliament amended the definition of money laundering under Section 3 of the Act to reconcile the same in accordance to the Vienna Convention and Palermo Convention, and to remove the deficiencies pointed out by the FATF in the Mutual Evaluation.
The definition of money laundering was thereby enlarged to include activities like concealment, acquisition, possession and use of proceeds of crime.
